sen.j: 新京阪鉄道（しんけいはんてつどう）は、京都府・大阪府に路線を有していた鉄道事業者。
sen.e: The Shinkeihan Railway was a railway company that owned railway lines in Kyoto and Osaka Prefectures.
The Shinkeihan Railway was a company that owned lines in Kyoto and Osaka prefectures.
The Shinkeihan Railway was a company that owned lines in Kyoto and Osaka prefectures.

sen.j: 現在の阪急京都本線系統にあたる鉄道路線を建設した。
sen.e: It built the railway lines which is known as the Hankyu Kyoto Line today.
It built the railway lines which are today known as the Hankyu Kyoto Line.
It built the railway lines which are today known as the Hankyu Kyoto Line.

sen.j: 京阪電気鉄道系の会社として、淀川西岸における新路線の敷設を行うために設立された。
sen.e: Shinkeihan Railway was established as a subsidiary of the Keihan Electric Railway in order to build a new railway line on the west coast of the Yodo-gawa River.
The Shinkeihan Railway was established as a subsidiary of the Keihan Electric Railway in order to build a new line on the western shore of the Yodo-gawa River.
The Shinkeihan Railway was established as a subsidiary of the Keihan Electric Railway in order to build a new line on the western shore of the Yodo-gawa River.

sen.j: 大正時代中期以降、阪神間においては阪神電気鉄道の阪神本線と阪神急行電鉄（阪急）の阪急神戸本線が激しい乗客獲得競争を繰り広げていた。
sen.e: Since the mid-Taisho period, the Hanshin Main Line operated by the Hanshin Electric Railway and the Hankyu Kobe Line operated by the Hanshin Electric Express Railway (or Hankyu) had been fiercely competing for customers between Osaka and Kobe.

Since the mid-Taisho period, the Hanshin Main Line operated by the Hanshin Electric Railway and the Hankyu Kobe Line operated by the Hanshin Electric Express Railway (or Hankyu) had been fiercely competing for customers between Osaka and Kobe.

Since the mid-Taisho period, the Hanshin Main Line operated by the Hanshin Electric Railway and the Hankyu Kobe Line operated by the Hanshin Electric Express Railway (or Hankyu) had been fiercely competing for customers between Osaka and Kobe.

sen.j: この状況を、阪神急行電鉄の前身である箕面有馬電気軌道が阪神間新線の免許を申請した時から見ていた京阪電気鉄道は、自社の保有する京阪本線に関する競合線が同様に出現し、利権が損なわれる事態へ発展することを危惧した。
sen.e: Having been watching this competition since the Mino-Arima Electric Tramline (Mino-Arima Denki Kido Company), the forerunner of the Hanshin Electric Express Railway, applied for a license to build a new railway line between Osaka and Kobe, the Keihan Electric Railway was seriously concerned about the possibility that a competitor might appear, jeopardizing its interests in the Keihan Main Line that it owned.

Having observed this competition since the Mino-Arima Electric Tramline (Mino-Arima Denki Kido Company), the forerunner of the Hanshin Electric Express Railway, the company applied for a license to build a new railway line between Osaka and Kobe; consequently, the Keihan Electric Railway was seriously concerned about the possibility that a competitor might appear and jeopardize its interests in the Keihan Main Line, which it owned.

Having observed this competition since the Mino-Arima Electric Tramline (Mino-Arima Denki Kido Company), the forerunner of the Hanshin Electric Express Railway, applied for a license to build a new railway line between Osaka and Kobe, the Keihan Electric Railway was seriously concerned about the possibility that a competitor might appear and jeopardize its interests in the Keihan Main Line, which it owned.
sen.cmt: 原文の意味となるように一部修正しました。

sen.j: この頃、京阪間の淀川右岸に高規格新線を敷設する計画が複数の企業から出ていたことから、京阪も自社線防衛を目的として地方鉄道法に基づく同様の路線免許の出願を行った。
sen.e: Around this time, a number of companies were developing plans to build new high-standard railway lines on the coast of the Yodo-gawa River and the Keihan Electric Railway also applied for a license to build a new line based on the Local Railways Act in order to defend its interests.
sen.cmt: 地方鉄道法→Local Railways Act[定訳は不明です。]
sen.e: Around this time, various companies were developing plans to build new high-standard railway lines along the Yodo-gawa River, and the Keihan Electric Railway also applied for a license to build a new line based on the Local Railways Act in order to defend its interests.

Around this time, various companies were developing plans to build new high-standard railway lines along the right bank of the Yodo-gawa River, and the Keihan Electric Railway also applied for a license to build a new line based on the Local Railways Act in order to defend its interests.
sen.cmt: 右岸 を追加しました。Yodo-gawa River→the Yodo-gawa Riverに変更しました。

sen.j: この免許申請は、鉄道省の阪神間のような熾烈競争を憂慮する考えと一致したことから認められ、その敷設を行うための子会社として新京阪鉄道が設立された。
sen.e: The license was granted by the Ministry of Railways, which was also concerned about the possibility of serious competition like that which arose between Osaka and Kobe, and the Shinkeihan Railway was established as a subsidiary of the Keihan Electric Railway in order to build the new line proposed.
sen.cmt: 鉄道省→Ministry of Railways[仮訳です。ご検討ください。]
sen.e: The license was granted by the Ministry of Railways, which was also concerned about the possibility of serious competition like that which arose between Osaka and Kobe; moreover, the Shinkeihan Railway was established as a subsidiary of the Keihan Electric Railway in order to build the new line thus proposed.

The license was granted by the Ministry of Railways, which was also concerned about the possibility of serious competition like that which arose between Osaka and Kobe; moreover, the Shinkeihan Railway was established as a subsidiary of the Keihan Electric Railway in order to build the new line thus proposed.

sen.j: 当初は、梅田に京阪本線と共用の総合ターミナル駅を設ける予定であったが、諸事情があって当面は実現できないと見られたため、十三駅～淡路駅～千里山駅間の路線を所有していた北大阪電気鉄道を買収し、同社の所有していた免許を利用して大阪市内の天神橋（天六）に暫定ターミナルを設けることとした。
sen.e: The original plan was to build a general terminal station in Umeda to be shared with the Keihan Main Line; however, since the plan was unlikely to be put into effect immediately due to various circumstances, the Keihan Electric Railway acquired the Kita-Osaka Electric Railway, which owned the railway line that ran from Juso Station to Awaji Station and to Senriyama Station, in order to build a temporary terminal in Tenjinbashi (Tenroku), Osaka City, using the license held by the company.
sen.cmt: 北大阪電気鉄道→Kita-Osaka Electric Railway[定訳は不明です。]
sen.e: The original plan was to build a general terminal station in Umeda to be shared with the Keihan Main Line; however, since the plan was unlikely to go into effect immediately due to various circumstances, the Keihan Electric Railway acquired the Kita-Osaka Electric Railway, which owned the railway line that ran from Juso Station to Awaji Station and Senriyama Station, in order to build a temporary terminal in Tenjinbashi (Tenroku), Osaka City, using the license held by the company.

The original plan was to build a general terminal station in Umeda to be shared with the Keihan Main Line; however, since the plan was unlikely to go into effect immediately due to various circumstances, the Keihan Electric Railway acquired the Kita-Osaka Electric Railway, which owned the railway line that ran from Juso Station to Awaji Station and Senriyama Station, in order to build a temporary terminal in Tenjinbashi (Tenroku), Osaka City, using the license held by the company.

sen.j: もっとも、暫定ターミナルとは言っても完成した天神橋駅は、アメリカのパシフィック電鉄などのインターアーバンのターミナルに範を取った、プラットホームを2階に設ける電鉄駅内蔵型高層ビルの日本における嚆矢となる当時としては破格の高層建築物であった。
sen.e: Although Tenjinbashi Station was built as a temporary terminal, it was the first station built in a high-rise building, extraordinary at the time, with platforms on its second floor, and was modeled after inter-urban railway terminals built by American companies like the Pacific Electric Railway.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処パシフィック電鉄→Pacific Electric Railway[http://homepage3.nifty.com/tract/pe-old.htm]
sen.e: Although Tenjinbashi Station was built as a temporary terminal, it was the first station built in a high-rise building--an extraordinary feat at the time--with platforms on its second floor, and was modeled after the inter-urban railway terminals built by American companies like the Pacific Electric Railway.

Although Tenjinbashi Station was built as a temporary terminal, it was the first station built in a high-rise building--an extraordinary feat at the time--with platforms on its second floor, and was modeled after the inter-urban railway terminals built by American companies like the Pacific Electric Railway.

sen.j: ここから新淀川橋梁直前まで続く鉄筋コンクリート造の高架橋ともども、そのコンセプトや基本設計は以後日本で開業することになる第2世代の都市間高速電車群の路線計画に多大な影響を与えた。
sen.e: Along with the design of the reinforced concrete viaduct that ran from the station to immediately before the Shin-Yodogawa Bridge, the concept and basic design of this station had a considerable influence on the railroad line plans of the second-generation inter-urban express railways that were subsequently operated in Japan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Along with the design of the reinforced concrete viaduct that ran from the station to immediately before the Shin-Yodogawa Bridge, the concept and basic design of this station had a considerable influence on the railroad-line plans of the second-generation inter-urban express railways that were subsequently operated in Japan.

Along with the design of the reinforced concrete viaduct that ran from the station to immediately before the Shin-Yodogawa Bridge, the concept and basic design of this station had a considerable influence on the railroad-line plans of the second-generation inter-urban express railways that were subsequently operated in Japan.

sen.j: また、京都側では地下線によって市内に乗り入れる予定であったが、工事には時間と多大な費用を要すること、そして昭和天皇即位の礼が京都御所で催されることになっていたことから、暫定的に市の外れ、葛野郡西院村に駅を設置し、ここから京都市電・京都市営バスなどで市街地へアクセスさせることにした。
sen.e: Meanwhile, a subway line was originally planned to be constructed to extend the line into Kyoto City; however, because of the large amount of time and high costs involved in the construction work and also because of the Emperor Showa's enthronement ceremony that was scheduled to be held at the Kyoto Imperial Palace, a plan was made to build a temporary terminal station in a suburb (Sai-mura, Kadono-gun) of Kyoto City and to provide access from there to the downtown area using the Kyoto CIty Tram service or Kyoto City Bus service.

Meanwhile, a subway line was originally planned to be constructed to extend the line into Kyoto City; however, due to the large investment of time and money involved in the construction work--and particularly due to the enthronement ceremony of Emperor Showa, which was scheduled to be held at the Kyoto Imperial Palace--a plan was made to build a temporary terminal station in a suburb (Sai-mura, Kadono-gun) of Kyoto City and to provide access from there to the downtown area using the Kyoto City Tram service or Kyoto City Bus service.

Meanwhile, a subway line was originally planned to be constructed to extend the line into Kyoto City; however, due to the large investment of time and money involved in the construction work--and particularly due to the enthronement ceremony of Emperor Showa, which was scheduled to be held at the Kyoto Imperial Palace--a plan was made to build a temporary terminal station in a suburb (Sai-mura, Kadono-gun) of Kyoto City and to provide access from there to the downtown area using the Kyoto City Tram service or Kyoto City Bus service.

sen.j: 1928年、天神橋駅～西院駅間を開業させたが、ほどなく1930年には京阪に吸収合併された。
sen.e: In 1928, the company started the railway service between Tenjinbashi Station and Saiin Station but in 1930, it was merged into the Keihan Electric Railway.
In 1928, the company started railway service between Tenjinbashi Station and Saiin Station, but in 1930 it was merged into the Keihan Electric Railway.
In 1928, the company started railway service between Tenjinbashi Station and Saiin Station, but in 1930 it was merged into the Keihan Electric Railway.

sen.j: これは昭和恐慌の影響もあり、新京阪のみならず本体の京阪も各方面への積極的な進出があだとなって多額の負債を抱えており、両社を統合して経営再建を図る目的があった。
sen.e: The parent company, Keihan Electric Railway, had a huge amount of liabilities as a result of its active investment in various areas during the Showa Depression and the merger was aimed at consolidating the two companies for business reorganization.

The parent company, Keihan Electric Railway, had a huge amount of liability as a result of its active investment in various areas during the Showa Depression, so the merger was aimed at consolidating the two companies for business reorganization.

The parent company, Keihan Electric Railway, had a huge amount of liability as a result of its active investment in various areas during the Showa Depression, so the merger was aimed at consolidating the two companies for business reorganization.

sen.j: なお京都市内への地下乗り入れに関しては、合併間もない1931年に大宮駅 (京都府)までの延伸という形で果たされている。
sen.e: The underground extension of the line into Kyoto City was achieved in 1931, soon after the merger, when the line was extended to Omiya Station (Kyoto Prefecture).
The underground extension of the line into Kyoto City was achieved in 1931, soon after the merger, when the line was extended to Omiya Station (Kyoto Prefecture).
The underground extension of the line into Kyoto City was achieved in 1931, soon after the merger, when the line was extended to Omiya Station (Kyoto Prefecture).

sen.j: また京阪グループでは、将来名古屋方面までの路線延長を計画していたが、これは恐慌の影響で立ち消えとなった。
sen.e: While the Keihan Group had a plan to extend the railway line to Nagoya, this plan was canceled as a result of the depression.
While the Keihan Group had a plan to extend the railway line to Nagoya, the plan was canceled as a result of the depression.
While the Keihan Group had a plan to extend the railway line to Nagoya, the plan was canceled as a result of the depression.

sen.j: 新京阪鉄道では、軌道や車両も当時の最高水準を実現していた。
sen.e: The Shinkeihan Railway built railroads and trains in accordance with the highest standards of the time.
The Shinkeihan Railway built railroads and trains in accordance with the highest standards of the time.
The Shinkeihan Railway built railroads and trains in accordance with the highest standards of the time.

sen.j: 特に1927年から製造した阪急100形電車は、全長19m・重量52トン・出力800馬力という当時日本で最大最強の高速電車であった。
sen.e: Hankyu Train Model 100, whose manufacture was started in 1927, was the largest and most powerful high-speed train manufactured in Japan at the time, with a total length of 19 m, a weight of 52 tons and a capacity of 800 horsepower.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Hankyu Train Model 100, whose manufacture was started in 1927, was the largest, most powerful high-speed train manufactured in Japan at the time, with a total length of 19 meters, a weight of 52 tons and a capacity of 800 horsepower.

Hankyu Train Model 100, whose manufacture was started in 1927, was the largest, most powerful high-speed train manufactured in Japan at the time, with a total length of nineteen meters, a weight of fifty-two tons and a capacity of 800 horsepower.
sen.cmt: 数字をスペルアウトしました。

sen.j: 日本国有鉄道東海道本線の特別急行列車「つばめ (列車)」を並行区間で追い抜いたという逸話で知られる。
sen.e: There is an anecdote about this train model, according to which it outstripped the special express train Tsubame on the section of a line running parallel to the Japan National Railway Company’s Tokaido Main Line.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: There is an anecdote about this train model, according to which it outstripped the special express train Tsubame on a section of a line running parallel to the Japan National Railway Company's Tokaido Main Line.

There is an anecdote about this train model, according to which it outstripped the special express train Tsubame on a section of a line running parallel to the Japan National Railway Company's Tokaido Main Line.

sen.j: 新京阪鉄道の沿線は人口過疎地域であったため、都市間輸送に専念するしか乗客獲得が見込めなかったことが、このような高性能電車を生む結果となった。
sen.e: This high-performance train model was created as a result of the fact that areas located along the Shinkeihan railway line being sparsely populated, the company could attract new customers only by specializing in inter-urban transportation.

This high-performance train model was created due to the fact that areas along the Shinkeihan railway line were sparsely populated, so the company could attract new customers only by specializing in inter-urban transportation.

This high-performance train model was created due to the fact that areas along the Shinkeihan railway line were sparsely populated, so the company could attract new customers only by specializing in inter-urban transportation.

sen.j: 戦中の1943年には京阪電気鉄道と阪神急行電鉄が合併し、京阪神急行電鉄（阪急、1973年に阪急電鉄と改称）となった。
sen.e: In 1943, during the Second World War, the Keihan Electric Railway and the Hanshin Electric Railway were merged into a single company by the name of the Keihanshin Express Railway (renamed the Hankyu Corporation in 1973).
sen.cmt: 京阪神急行電鉄→Keihanshin Express Railway[定訳は不明です。]
sen.e: In 1943, during the Second World War, the Keihan Electric Railway and Hanshin Electric Railway were merged into a single company called the Keihanshin Express Railway (which was renamed the Hankyu Corporation in 1973).

In 1943, during the Second World War, the Keihan Electric Railway and Hanshin Electric Express Railway were merged into a single company called the Keihanshin Express Railway (which was renamed the Hankyu Corporation in 1973).

sen.j: 戦後の1949年に京阪電鉄が京阪神急行から分離した際、元新京阪の路線は阪急に残り、京都本線・千里線・阪急嵐山線になった。
sen.e: After the end of the war, when the Keihan Railway split from the Keihanshin Express Railway in 1949, former Shinkeihan railway lines remained in the possession of the Hankyu Corporation and were operated as the Kyoto Main Line, the Senri Line and the Hankyu Arashiyama Line.

After the end of the war, when the Keihan Railway split from the Keihanshin Express Railway in 1949, former Shinkeihan railway lines remained in the possession of the Hankyu Corporation and were operated as the Kyoto Main Line, the Senri Line and the Hankyu Arashiyama Line.

After the end of the war, when the Keihan Railway split from the Keihanshin Express Railway in 1949, former Shinkeihan railway lines remained in the possession of the Hankyu Corporation and were operated as the Kyoto Line, the Senri Line and the Hankyu Arashiyama Line.

sen.j: なお京阪分離前の1945年からは、新京阪線電車の梅田駅乗り入れが開始されており、これが新京阪線系統の路線が阪急に残存する一要因になったのではないかとも言われている。
sen.e: In 1945, before the Keihan Railway gained independence, the Shinkeihan Line was extended to Umeda, which is believed to have been one of the reasons why the former Shinkeihan lines remained in the possession of the Hankyu Corporation.

In 1945, before the Keihan Railway became independent, the Shinkeihan Line was extended to Umeda, which is believed to have been one of the reasons the former Shinkeihan lines remained in the possession of the Hankyu Corporation.

In 1945, before the Keihan Railway became independent, the Shinkeihan Line was extended to Umeda, which is believed to have been one of the reasons the former Shinkeihan lines remained in the possession of the Hankyu Corporation.

sen.j: このような歴史的経緯から、京都本線系統の各線は、車両技術や施設面において阪急が自社建設した軌道条例→軌道法由来の路線とは多く異なる面があった。
sen.e: Due to this historical background, lines that were part of the Kyoto Line differed in many respects from the lines that were developed by the Hankyu Corporation on its own based on the Tramways Ordinance or the Tramways Act.
sen.cmt: 軌道条例→Tramways ordinance[定訳は不明です。]軌道法→Tramways Act[英辞郎 on the WEB]
sen.e: Given such circumstances, the lines that were part of the Kyoto Line differed in many respects from the lines that the Hankyu Corporation developed on its own, based on the Tramways Ordinance or the Tramways Act.

Given such circumstances, the lines that were part of the Kyoto Line differed in many respects from the lines that the Hankyu Corporation developed on its own, based on the Tramways Ordinance or the Tramways Act.

sen.j: そのため現在でも、阪急自身が建設した神戸線・阪急宝塚線系統の各路線を「神宝線」と総称し、京都本線系統の各線と区別することがある。
sen.e: Even today, lines that are part of the Kobe Line and the Hankyu Takarazuka Line, which were built by the Hankyu Railway, are sometimes subsumed under a single general category, the Jimpo-sen Line, to distinguish them from the lines that are part of the former Kyoto Line.

Even today, lines that are part of the Kobe and Hankyu Takarazuka lines, which were built by the Hankyu Railway, are sometimes subsumed under a single general category--the Jimpo-sen Line--to distinguish them from the lines that are part of the former Kyoto Line.

Even today, lines that are part of the Kobe and Hankyu Takarazuka lines, which were built by the Hankyu Railway, are sometimes subsumed under a single general category--the Jinpo Line--to distinguish them from the lines that are part of the former Kyoto Line.

tit.e: History of the Establishment of the Shinkeihan Railway
History of the Shinkeihan Railway's Establishment

sen.j: 1918年（大正7年）4月16日 京阪電気鉄道、軌道条例に基づく淀川西岸支線出願。
sen.e: On April 16, 1918, the Keihan Electric Railway applied for a license to build a branch line on the west coast of the Yodo-gawa River (Yodogawa Seigan Line) based on the Tramways Ordinance.
April 16, 1918: The Keihan Electric Railway applied for a license to build a branch line on the western edge of the Yodo-gawa River (Yodogawa Seigan Line) based on the Tramways Ordinance.
April 16, 1918: The Keihan Electric Railway applied for a license to build a branch line on the western edge of the Yodo-gawa River (Yodogawa Seigan Line) based on the Tramways Ordinance.

sen.j: 1918年（大正7年）12月27日 延長線追願（山崎、長岡、桂、西京極、西院、四条大宮）。
sen.e: On December 27, 1918, the company submitted an additional request for permission to extend its line (through Yamazaki, Nagaoka, Katsura, Nishikyogoku and Saiin to Shijo Omiya).
December 27, 1918, The company submitted an additional request for permission to extend its line through Yamazaki, Nagaoka, Katsura, Nishikyogoku and Saiin to Shijo Omiya.
December 27, 1918, The company submitted an additional request for permission to extend its line through Yamazaki, Nagaoka, Katsura, Nishikyogoku and Saiin to Shijo Omiya.

sen.j: 1919年（大正8年）7月21日 京阪電気鉄道に対して、特許状及び命令書→付帯命令あり。
sen.e: July 21, 1919: A license with government orders was issued to the Keihan Electric Railway.
July 21, 1919: A license with government orders was issued to the Keihan Electric Railway.
July 21, 1919: A license with government orders was issued to the Keihan Electric Railway.

sen.j: 1920年（大正9年）2月21日 京阪電気鉄道、城東線払い下げ願書提出。
sen.e: February 21, 1920: The Keihan Electric Railway submitted a request that the Joto Line be sold to the company.
February 21, 1920: The Keihan Electric Railway submitted a request that the Joto Line be sold to the company.
February 21, 1920: The Keihan Electric Railway submitted a request that the Joto Line be sold to the company.

sen.j: 1920年（大正9年）5月20日 京阪電気鉄道に対して、払い下げ許可の内諾。
sen.e: May 20, 1920: An unofficial approval was given to the Keihan Electric Railway to purchase the Joto Line from the government.
May 20, 1920: An unofficial approval was given to the Keihan Electric Railway to purchase the Joto Line from the government.
May 20, 1920: An unofficial approval was given to the Keihan Electric Railway to purchase the Joto Line from the government.

sen.j: 1920年（大正9年）5月24日 京阪電気鉄道、北区葉村町を淀川西岸船の大阪起点に変更する旨の申請書を提出。
sen.e: May 24, 1920: The Keihan Electric Railway submitted a request to change the starting point of the Yodogawa Seigan Line in Osaka to Hamura-cho, Kita Ward.
sen.cmt: 「淀川西岸船」は「淀川西岸線」の誤りだと考え、そのように訳しました。
sen.e: May 24, 1920: The Keihan Electric Railway submitted a request to change the starting point of the Yodogawa Seigan Line in Osaka to Hamura-cho, Kita Ward.
May 24, 1920: The Keihan Electric Railway submitted a request to change the starting point of the Yodogawa Seigan Line in Osaka to Hamura-cho, Kita Ward.

sen.j: 1921年（大正10年）11月14日 京阪電気鉄道、軌道特許を地方鉄道免許に変更。
sen.e: November 14, 1921: The Keihan Electric Railway changed its tramway license to a local railway license.
November 14, 1921: The Keihan Electric Railway changed its tramway license to a local railway license.
November 14, 1921: The Keihan Electric Railway changed its tramway license to a local railway license.

sen.j: 1922年（大正11年）4月25日 京阪電気鉄道、地方鉄道法による許可取得。
sen.e: On April 25, 1922, the Keihan Electric Railway obtained a permission to operate railways based on the Local Railway Act.
April 25, 1922: the Keihan Electric Railway obtained permission to operate railways based on the Local Railway Act.
April 25, 1922: the Keihan Electric Railway obtained permission to operate railways based on the Local Railway Act.

sen.j: 1922年（大正11年）6月28日 新京阪鉄道創立。
sen.e: The Shinkeihan Railway was established on June 28, 1922.
The Shinkeihan Railway was established on June 28, 1922.
June 28, 1922: The Shinkeihan Railway was established.

sen.j: 1923年（大正12年）4月1日 北大阪電気鉄道から鉄道事業を譲受。
sen.e: On April 1, 1923, the Shinkeihan Railway started its railway business as the successor to the Kita-Osaka Electric Railway.
On April 1, 1923, the Shinkeihan Railway started its railway business as the successor to the Kita-Osaka Electric Railway.
April 1, 1923: The Shinkeihan Railway started its railway business as the successor to the Kita-Osaka Electric Railway.

sen.j: 1923年（大正12年）6月18日 淡路～上新庄免許。
sen.e: On June 18, 1923, the Shinkeihan Railway obtained a license to operate the railway line between Awaji and Kamishinjo.
On June 18, 1923, the Shinkeihan Railway obtained a license to operate the railway line between Awaji and Kamishinjo.
June 18, 1923: The Shinkeihan Railway obtained a license to operate the railway line between Awaji and Kamishinjo.

sen.j: 1923年（大正12年）9月5日 新京阪鉄道、十三～稗島地方鉄道敷設免許。
sen.e: On September 5, 1923, the Shinkeihan Railway obtained a license to build a local railway line between Juso and Hiejima.
On September 5, 1923, the Shinkeihan Railway obtained a license to build a local railway line between Juso and Hiejima.
September 5, 1923: The Shinkeihan Railway obtained a license to build a local railway line between Juso and Hiejima.

sen.j: 1924年（大正13年）5月13日 新京阪鉄道、長岡天神～柳谷観音地方鉄道免許。
sen.e: On May 13, 1924, the Shinkeihan Railway obtained a license to operate the local railway line between Nagaokatenjin and Yanagidani Kannon.
On May 13, 1924, the Shinkeihan Railway obtained a license to operate the local railway line between Nagaokatenjin and Yanagidani Kannon.
May 13, 1924: The Shinkeihan Railway obtained a license to operate the local railway line between Nagaokatenjin and Yanagidani Kannon.

sen.j: 1925年（大正14年）6月15日 新京阪鉄道、西吹田から高槻に至る第二の支線計画を申請。
sen.e: On June 15, 1925, the Shinkeihan Railway submitted a plan to build a second branch line that ran between Nishi-Suita and Takatsuki.
On June 15, 1925, the Shinkeihan Railway submitted a plan to build a second branch line that ran between Nishi-Suita and Takatsuki.
June 15, 1925: The Shinkeihan Railway submitted a plan to build a second branch line that ran between Nishi-Suita and Takatsuki.

sen.j: 1925年（大正15年）10月15日 天神橋～淡路開業
sen.e: On October 15, 1925, the railway service between Tenjinbashi and Awaji started.
On October 15, 1925, the railway service between Tenjinbashi and Awaji started.
October 15, 1925: The railway service between Tenjinbashi and Awaji started.

sen.j: 1926年（大正15年）3月22日 新京阪鉄道、第二の支線計画を若干変更したものを届け出。
sen.e: On March 22, 1926, the Shinkeihan Railway submitted a plan for the second branch line with changes made to it.
On March 22, 1926, the Shinkeihan Railway submitted a plan for the second branch line, incorporating certain changes.
March 22, 1926: The Shinkeihan Railway submitted a plan for the second branch line, incorporating certain changes.

sen.j: 1926年（大正15年）7月5日 下新庄～正雀軌道着工。
sen.e: On July 5, 1926, the construction of the railway line between Shimoshinjo and Shojaku was started.
On July 5, 1926, the construction of the railway line between Shimoshinjo and Shojaku commenced.
July 5, 1926: The construction of the railway line between Shimoshinjo and Shojaku commenced.

sen.j: 1926年（大正15年）9月15日 茨木町～高槻町着工。
sen.e: On September 15, 1926, the construction of the railway line between Ibaraki-cho and Takatsuki-cho was started.
On September 15, 1926, the construction of the railway line between Ibaraki-cho and Takatsuki-cho was started.
September 15, 1926: The construction of the railway line between Ibaraki-cho and Takatsuki-cho was started.

sen.j: 1926年（大正15年）9月27日 新京阪鉄道、京都市と西院～四条河原町地下敷設契約を締結。
sen.e: On September 27, 1926, the Shinkeihan Railway concluded an agreement with Kyoto City to build a subway line between Saiin and Shijo Kawaramachi.
On September 27, 1926, the Shinkeihan Railway concluded an agreement with Kyoto City to build a subway line between Saiin and Shijo Kawaramachi.
September 27, 1926: The Shinkeihan Railway concluded an agreement with Kyoto City to build a subway line between Saiin and Shijo Kawaramachi.

sen.j: 1926年（大正15年）12月1日 高槻町～島本村着工。
sen.e: On December 1, 1926, the construction of the line between Takatsuki-cho and Shimamoto-mura was started.
On December 1, 1926, the construction of the line between Takatsuki-cho and Shimamoto-mura was started.
December 1, 1926: The construction of the line between Takatsuki-cho and Shimamoto-mura was started.

sen.j: 1927年（昭和2年）1月28日 正雀～茨木町着工。
sen.e: On January 28, 1927, the construction of the line between Shojaku and Ibaraki-cho was started.
On January 28, 1927, the construction of the line between Shojaku and Ibaraki-cho was started.
January 28, 1927: The construction of the line between Shojaku and Ibaraki-cho was started.

sen.j: 1927年（昭和2年）9月 大山崎～向日町着工。
sen.e: In September 1927, the construction of the line between Oyamazaki and Mukomachi was started.
In September 1927, the construction of the line between Oyamazaki and Mukomachi was initiated.
September 1927: The construction of the line between Oyamazaki and Mukomachi was initiated.

sen.j: 1927年（昭和2年）10月18日 新京阪鉄道、大宮～河原町免許取得。
sen.e: On October 18, 1927, the Shinkeihan Railway obtained a license to operate the railway line between Omiya and Kawaramachi.
On October 18, 1927, the Shinkeihan Railway obtained a license to operate the railway line between Omiya and Kawaramachi.
October 18, 1927: the Shinkeihan Railway obtained a license to operate the railway line between Omiya and Kawaramachi.

sen.j: 1927年（昭和2年）11月19日 正雀車庫竣工（1928年2月1日使用開始）。
sen.e: On November 19, 1927, the construction of the Shojaku Train Depot was completed (the depot started to be used on February 1, 1928).
On November 19, 1927, the construction of the Shojaku Train Depot was completed (the depot went into operation on February 1, 1928).
November 19, 1927: The construction of the Shojaku Train Depot was completed (the depot went into operation on February 1, 1928).

sen.j: 1927年（昭和2年）11月29日 新京阪鉄道、京都西院～四条大宮の工事施行認可。
sen.e: On November 29, 1927, the Shinkeihan Railway obtained a permission to build a railway line between Kyoto Saiin and Shijo Omiya.
On November 29, 1927, the Shinkeihan Railway obtained permission to build a railway line between Kyoto Saiin and Shijo Omiya.
November 29, 1927: The Shinkeihan Railway obtained permission to build a railway line between Kyoto Saiin and Shijo Omiya.

sen.j: 1928年（昭和3年）1月16日 淡路～高槻町開業。
sen.e: On January 16, 1928, the railway service between Awaji and Takatsuki-cho was started.
On January 16, 1928, the railway service between Awaji and Takatsuki-cho was started.
January 16, 1928: The railway service between Awaji and Takatsuki-cho was started.

sen.j: 架線電圧を1500Vに昇圧。
sen.e: The line voltage was increased to 1500 V.
The line voltage was increased to 1500 V.
The line voltage was increased to 1500 V.

sen.j: 1928年（昭和3年）2月 桂～西京極着工。
sen.e: In February 1928, the construction of the line between Katsura and Nishi-Kyogoku was started.
In February 1928, the construction of the line between Katsura and Nishi-Kyogoku commenced.
February, 1928: The construction of the line between Katsura and Nishi-Kyogoku commenced.

sen.j: 1928年（昭和3年）10月20日 桂車庫竣工。
sen.e: On October 20, 1928, the construction of the Katsura Train Depot was completed.
On October 20, 1928, the construction of the Katsura Train Depot was completed.
October 20, 1928: The construction of the Katsura Train Depot was completed.

sen.j: 1928年（昭和3年）10月30日 向日町変電所竣工。
sen.e: On October 30, 1928, the construction of the Mukomachi Substation was completed.
On October 30, 1928, the construction of the Mukomachi Substation was completed.
October 30, 1928: The construction of the Mukomachi Substation was completed.

sen.j: 1928年（昭和3年）11月1日 高槻町～西院（仮駅）間開業。
sen.e: On November 1, 1928, the railway service between Takatsuki-cho and Saiin (temporary station) was started.
On November 1, 1928, the railway service between Takatsuki-cho and Saiin (temporary station) was started.
November 1, 1928: The railway service between Takatsuki-cho and Saiin (temporary station) was started.

sen.j: 1928年（昭和3年）11月9日 桂～嵐山開業。
sen.e: On November 9, 1928, the railway service between Katsura and Arashiyama was started.
On November 9, 1928, the railway service between Katsura and Arashiyama was initiated.
November 9, 1928: The railway service between Katsura and Arashiyama was initiated.

sen.j: 1928年（昭和3年）6月12日 名古屋急行電鉄、大津市～名古屋の鉄道敷設免許出願。
sen.e: On June 12, 1928, the Nagoya Express Railway applied for a license to build a railway line between Otsu City and Nagoya.
sen.cmt: 名古屋急行電鉄→Nagoya Express Railway (名古屋急行電鉄) [定訳は不明です。]
sen.e: On June 12, 1928, the Nagoya Express Railway applied for a license to build a railway line between Otsu City and Nagoya.
June 12, 1928: The Nagoya Express Railway applied for a license to build a railway line between Otsu City and Nagoya.

sen.j: 1928年（昭和3年）6月15日 京都地下線、西院～西大路四条着工。
sen.e: On June 15, 1928, the construction of the Kyoto subway line between Saiin and Nishioji Shijo was started.
On June 15, 1928, the construction of the Kyoto subway line between Saiin and Nishioji Shijo was started.
June 15, 1928: The construction of the Kyoto subway line between Saiin and Nishioji Shijo was started.

sen.j: 1928年（昭和3年）9月16日 正雀車両工場竣工。
sen.e: On September 16, 1928, the construction of the Shojaku Train Factory was completed.
On September 16, 1928, the construction of the Shojaku Train Factory was completed.
September 16, 1928: The construction of the Shojaku Train Factory was completed.

sen.j: 1929年（昭和4年）10月14日 第二の支線計画却下。
sen.e: On October 14, 1929, the Shinkeihan Railway's plan for its second branch line was rejected.
On October 14, 1929, the Shinkeihan Railway's plan for its second branch line was rejected.
October 14, 1929: The Shinkeihan Railway's plan for its second branch line was rejected.

sen.j: 1929年（昭和4年）2月20日 京都地下線、道路下区間工事準備。
sen.e: On February 20, 1929, preparations for the construction of the section of the Kyoto subway line running beneath roads were started.
On February 20, 1929, preparations started for the construction of the section of the Kyoto subway line running beneath roads.
February 20, 1929: Preparations started for the construction of the section of the Kyoto subway line running beneath roads.
sen.cmt: 日付統一On February 20, 1929,→February 20, 1929:に変更しました。

sen.j: 1929年（昭和4年）6月29日 京阪電気鉄道、名古屋急行電鉄免許。
sen.e: On June 29, 1929, the Keihan Electric Railway obtained a license to operate the Nagoya Express Railway.
On June 29, 1929, the Keihan Electric Railway obtained a license to operate the Nagoya Express Railway.
June 29, 1929: The Keihan Electric Railway obtained a license to operate the Nagoya Express Railway.

sen.j: 1929年（昭和4年）7月1日 京都地下線、道路下区間鉄矢板打ち込み開始。
sen.e: On July 1, 1929, the driving of iron sheet piles for the construction of the Kyoto subway line running beneath roads was started.
On July 1, 1929, the process of driving iron-sheet piles for the construction of the Kyoto subway line running beneath roads was started.
July 1, 1929: The process of driving iron-sheet piles for the construction of the Kyoto subway line running beneath roads was started.

sen.j: 1929年（昭和4年）8月11日 京都地下線、専用区間竣工。
sen.e: On August 11, 1929, the construction of the dedicated sections of the Kyoto subway line was completed.
On August 11, 1929, the construction of the dedicated sections of the Kyoto subway line was completed.
August 11, 1929: The construction of the dedicated sections of the Kyoto subway line was completed.

sen.j: 1930年（昭和5年）1月20日 京都地下線、道路下区間掘削開始。
sen.e: On January 20, 1930, excavation for the construction of the Kyoto subway line section running beneath roads was started.
On January 20, 1930, excavation for the construction of the Kyoto subway line section running beneath roads was started.
January 20, 1930: Excavation for the construction of the Kyoto subway line section running beneath roads was started.

sen.j: 1930年（昭和5年）2月27日 長岡天神～柳谷観音間の免許失効。
sen.e: On February 27, 1930, the license for the line between Nagaokatenjin and Yanagidani Kannon expired.
On February 27, 1930, the license for the line between Nagaokatenjin and Yanagidani Kannon expired.
February 27, 1930: The license for the line between Nagaokatenjin and Yanagidani Kannon expired.

sen.j: 1930年（昭和5年）4月21日 天神橋～西院に超特急運転開始。
sen.e: On April 21, 1930, super-express train service was started between Tenjinbashi and Saiin.
On April 21, 1930, super-express train service was launched between Tenjinbashi and Saiin.
April 21, 1930: Super-express train service was launched between Tenjinbashi and Saiin.

sen.j: 1930年（昭和5年）6月17日 京阪電気鉄道、新京阪鉄道との合併仮契約。
sen.e: On June 17, 1930, the Keihan Electric Railway concluded an interim merger contract with the Shinkeihan Railway.
On June 17, 1930, the Keihan Electric Railway concluded an interim merger contract with the Shinkeihan Railway.
June 17, 1930: The Keihan Electric Railway concluded an interim merger contract with the Shinkeihan Railway.

sen.j: 1930年（昭和5年）6月23日 京都地下線、道路下区間構築開始。
sen.e: On June 23, 1930, the construction of the Kyoto subway line section beneath roads was started.
On June 23, 1930, the construction of the Kyoto subway line section beneath roads was started.
June 23, 1930: The construction of the Kyoto subway line section beneath roads was started.

sen.j: 1930年（昭和5年）9月15日 京阪電気鉄道、新京阪鉄道を合併。
sen.e: On September 15, 1930, the Shinkeihan Railway was merged into the Keihan Electric Railway.
On September 15, 1930, the Shinkeihan Railway was merged into the Keihan Electric Railway.
September 15, 1930: The Shinkeihan Railway was merged into the Keihan Electric Railway.

sen.j: 1931年（昭和6年）3月31日 新京阪線の京都地下線、西院～京阪京都（大宮）開業。
sen.e: On March 31, 1931, subway service was started on the Shinkeihan Line between Saiin and Keihan Kyoto (Omiya).
On March 31, 1931, subway service was started on the Shinkeihan Line between Saiin and Keihan Kyoto (Omiya).
March 31, 1931: Subway service was started on the Shinkeihan Line between Saiin and Keihan Kyoto (Omiya).

sen.j: 1934年（昭和9年）9月1日 十三～京都直通急行列車運転開始。
sen.e: On September 1, 1934, direct express train service between Juso and Kyoto was started.
On September 1, 1934, direct express train service between Juso and Kyoto commenced.
September 1, 1934: Direct express train service between Juso and Kyoto commenced.

sen.j: その後一時休止。
sen.e: This service was subsequently suspended for a brief period of time.
This service was subsequently suspended for a brief period of time.
This service was subsequently suspended for a brief period of time.

sen.j: 1935年（昭和10年）7月8日 名古屋急行電鉄、工事施行期限延長却下。
sen.e: On July 8, 1935, the Nagoya Express Railway's request for the prolongation of the construction period was rejected.
On July 8, 1935, the Nagoya Express Railway's request to prolong the construction period was rejected.
July 8, 1935: The Nagoya Express Railway's request to prolong the construction period was rejected.

sen.j: 1941年（昭和16年）11月1日 十三～京都直通急行列車運転再開。
sen.e: On November 1, 1941, the direct express train service between Juso and Kyoto was restarted.
On November 1, 1941, the direct express train service between Juso and Kyoto was restarted.
November 1, 1941: The direct express train service between Juso and Kyoto was restarted.

sen.j: 1943年（昭和18年）10月1日 京阪電気鉄道と阪神急行電鉄が合併、京阪神急行電鉄になる。
sen.e: On October 1, 1943, the Keihan Electric Railway and the Hanshin Express Railway were merged into the Keihanshin Express Railway.
On October 1, 1943, the Keihan Electric Railway and the Hanshin Express Railway were merged into the Keihanshin Express Railway.
October 1, 1943: The Keihan Electric Railway and the Hanshin Express Railway were merged into the Keihanshin Express Railway.

sen.j: これ以降は阪急京都本線、阪急電鉄、阪急阪神ホールディングスを参照。
sen.e: For the subsequent history, see articles on the Hankyu Kyoto Line, the Hankyu Corporation and the Hankyu Hanshin Holdings.

sen.j: 京阪電気鉄道時代、1931年の西院～京阪京都間開業時点。
